bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 6, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas relays further information about the manning of ambulance sections in France. He mentions a possible misunderstanding between the French and American authorities.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 6, 1917
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
October 6,1917.
wcg-hhw
Rico Nov 24
Colonel J.R. Kean,
Medical Corps, U.S. Army,
American Expeditionary Force,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of September the 6th was received some
days ago. I appreciate the need that you and Bradley must
feel about getting news from home. I feel the same way
with regard to you and Bradley. I am having Bradley sent
carbon copies of everything that goes on in the office that
may give him information. If you and he are separated and
you have no access to this matter I will also have you sent
a carbon copies. I can see from your letter that you
have misunderstood the status of the ambulance sections.
The matter was considered when the war first broke out by a
request from the French Embassy that we take over the trans-
portation of the French wounded. After extended discussion
with the military attaché at the Embassy it was agreed that
we should form 160 sections for this purpose. When the
French Mission came over, headed by General Joffre, he and
the Secretary of War came to an agreement on the subject
which was substantially this: That we should furnish the
French Army 160 ambulance sections, as at present organized.
Each section to be paid and cared for by the U.S. Army, just as
any other troops serving in Europe. The idea of theThe idea of the
2.
Secretary of War was that these sections should go right
into active service, thereby getting experience that
would be useful to us, and that, as we needed them we would
draw them off for use in our army, but replace each
section that we took away by another one from the United
States. We made the same agreement with the English
Embassy with regard to American troops sent for service
with the English Army, and this is what we are doing at
present so far as the English service is concerned.

The whole thing was smashed up by General Pershing's
cable saying that he wanted no more ambulance sections
for France, that the French authorities had so stated to
him. Upon the receipt of this cable we prepared to dis-
tribute our sections at Allentown to the various cantonments
for the purpose of expanding them into the Ambulance companies
for the Divisions under training.

The French Embassy, however, begs me to wait until they
can get some communication from their Government. They were
cognizant of our promise to Gen. Joffre, and say that they
know General Pershing has misunderstood what their Government
wishes. Get the matter settled as soon as you can if
the French wish any more ambulance sections. I would like to
break up Allentown as soon as it is decided we have no more use
for it.

So far we have complied with all the cablegrams that
3.
concern you. We have cabled that the Secretary authorizes
9 more sections to be taken over in France.

In response to your last cable we have forwarded 10 more
sections and 300 unassigned men. I judge, therefore, you
have authority now to take over all the sections in France
which you had in view at the time of writing your letter.

You know whom Mr. McFadden is - a son of Mr. McFadden
who was so prominent before the war in scientific research in
London in connection with Sir Ronald Ross.

You understand that we are limited as to officers by
the organization prescribed by the War College. Within these
limits I expect to carry out everything you recommend in the
way of commissions. I will keep you informed of the men and
numbers who have so far been commissioned. You understand
that our general policy is to fill the ambulance sections as
much as we consider desirable with men who are not M.D's. But
until particularly needed, the M.D's., I think, you might as well
use and give them training.

Birmingham has no doubt arrived by this time and he will
give you all the news up to date.
Mrs. Gorgas joins me in kindest regards.
